awd_titl_txt: Development of a Simulation-Based Application for Teaching Human Physiology through Guided Discovery, Pure Discovery, and Authentic Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Florida has received an NSF Improving Undergraduate STEM Education Exploration Track award to develop a web application with which undergraduate students can learn human physiology using both guided and pure discovery. The Principal Investigator (PI) team will design, conduct and analyze the results of authentic, simulation-based research. In contrast to many of the existing simulations commercially-available for human physiology instruction, the systematic model that forms the foundation of this project was created for basic and applied physiology research. The most recent iteration, called HumMod, is the most comprehensive model of human physiology, with over 6,000 variables describing cardiovascular, respiratory, renal, neural, endocrine, skeletal muscle, and metabolic physiology constructed from empirical data from peer-reviewed physiological literature.  HumMod accurately predicts qualitative and quantitative changes in both clinical and experimental responses, and can simulate both acute and chronic clinical scenarios. 

Based on the use of previous work involving the use of HumMod in physiology classes, it was recognized that it is a valuable guided-discovery tool for authentic, simulation-based research undergraduate physiology courses. However, the work demonstrated that the comprehensiveness that makes HumMod an outstanding research tool also makes it daunting for use as an education tool. To that end, the PI team will design a user interface that will simplify HumMod so that it can be used as an effective tool for student guided- or pure-discovery research in the classroom.  The PI team also will investigate how instructional strategies for the simulation can be optimized to promote flexible and generalizable reasoning. Theories of learning are in direct conflict on how to manage the learner's efforts.  Cognitive load theorists (CLT) emphasize the need for guided discovery to minimize extraneous load; while error management theorists (EMT) suggest pure discovery to promote higher-level cognitive processes and active learning. The PI team will experimentally compare the two approaches to determine an effective application design and teaching strategy for undergraduate human physiology instruction.  This project is funded jointly by the Directorate for Biological Sciences, Division of Biological Infrastructure and the Directorate for Education and Human Resources, Division of Undergraduate Education in support of efforts to address the challenges posed in Vision and Change in Undergraduate Education: A Call to Action http://visionandchange.org/finalreport/.

por.por_cntn:
Student-centered, active-learning approaches to teaching allow the student to lead the learning process. This can range from guided discovery (also called guided-inquiry) to pure discovery methods, and from guided research to authentic research (in which students take the lead in developing the hypothesis and experimental design and analyzing the results). Computer-based simulations are particularly valuable tools for promoting student-centered, active learning. In comparison with textbooks and lectures, a computer simulation can allow students to systematically explore hypothetical situations, interact with a simplified version of a process or system, and change the timescale of events. Human physiology is highly complex and dynamic, with even small perturbations causing cascades of responses in multiple organ systems, and therefore it is particulary well suited for instruction using a computer-based simulation.

In this project, we developed JustPhysiology (www.justphysiology.com, Fig. 1), a web-based cyberlearning tool designed to support undergraduate students in learning human physiology through authentic inquiry practices that include formulating questions, hypothesis development, data collection, and theory revision. JustPhysiology is based on HumMod, an 11,000-variable mathematical model of human physiology that has been under continuous development at the University of Mississippi Medical Center since 1970.

The JustPhysiology application allows students to examine physiological relationships between cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, endocrine, and metabolic systems as the body responds to challenges such as exercise, hemorrhage, hypoxia, hypothermia, physical trauma, and starvation, as well as changes in system, organ, and tissue function associated with a variety of acute and chronic disease conditions (Fig. 2). Learning modules consist of labs, lessons, and case studies, with the the latter providing narrative-based structures in which students can conduct experiments, diagnose patients, and provide medical treatments (Fig. 3).

The usability and usefulness of JustPhysiology was tested in undergraduate biology and physiology courses at four institutions. Usability study participants agreed that the system was easy to use, the various functions were well integrated, they felt confident using the system, and they felt that most people would learn to use this system very quickly. The participants overwhelmingly agreed that using JustPhysiology simulations helped them understand the course material better, that it had a positive effect on their interest in physiology, and that using JustPhysiology helped them feel more confident in the course. Students who completed semester-long authentic research projects using JustPhysiology showed similar outcomes in their opinions about science and learning compared to students who complete traditional, course-based undergraduate research experiences.

The JustPhysiology cyberlearning application provides opportunities for students to engage in the fundamental principles and concepts of physiology in novel ways, including model-based, authentic research. It is expected that this will increase students' foundational knowledge in the life sciences, increase their persistence in the life sciences, and may increase the interest of more undergraduates in careers in physiology research.
